title: Van Gogh's Starry Night TSP Single Line Drawing

description.text: Van Gogh's Starry Night as a TSP Single Line Drawing I tried this same image numerous times with very different settings. Changing the image's size, contrast, and reducing the color levels drastically affect the tone and quality of the finished product. These two SVG's were the best of the bunch. Some were a huge horrible jumbled mess and others were so sparse as to look like a pile of noodles. Unfortunately, since both have so many lines in them, they are both very unsuitable to small line drawings. However, I think they might be prefect for my DrawBot. http://makerblock.com/tag/drawbot/
Tutorial here: makerbot.com/blog/2012/03/12/single-line-art-traveling-salesman-problem-tutorial/

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Y motor mount mod (damper + robustness)

description.text:
Tested with EMVIO NEMA 17 dampers

Update 11/12/2016
Added a V2 (wider).
It seems that no matter how hard you try, the part (and thus the motor) will eventually bend if you print the mount with PETG. I can then only sugget to print the V2 with ABS, 80% cubic infill.

------
Standard Y-motor mount of Prusa i3 MK2 suffers from 2 problems:

  • only 2 screw points don't allow the installation of a NEMA17 damper;
  • the mount is a bit flimsy; after some days, the motor bents slightly and causes the belt to slip over the pulley border (see photo). Not that big problem I know. Note that the X motor mount doesn't bend, and it's 17mm wide against 10mm of the Y motor mount...

Some other projects and things fix the first problem:

  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1837853
  • https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iJrjFo03urM-y-motor-damper

An additional part from Prusa fixes the second problem:

  • https://github.com/prusa3d/Original-Prusa-i3/blob/MK2/Printed-Parts/stl/Y-distance.stl

The two solutions, however, don't work well together, because the Y-distance would actually add a coupling surface from the motor to the printer, reducing the effectiveness of the damper.

This thing tries to fix both problems in one shot:
1) a bracket for third screw is added;
2) the overall width of the part is increased from 10mm to 12mm, so no Y-distance part is needed, supposing the added roubstness will make it stiffer (to be tested);
3) the original SCAD file is used.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

80% cubic

Notes:

print with ABS (no PETG - it will bend)
The same original M3x10 screws can be used.

I designed a E-pipe body to fit 2 x 16500's in parralel. The top battery terminal connection is still a problem and I had to McGiuver it with a couple of bits of sheetmetal, but it works sell. if you come up with a battery terminal solution let me know please. I am considering putting a usb charger inside and soldering the terminals. there is some spare space inside.

It is a fairly large pipe but it packs massive horsepower with the twin 18500 and runns all day at 30W where I like to vape. The devisions on my black mat is 10mm per square for reference. I will work on a twin 18350/16350 soon if I can find good enough battery cells. That will make it much smaller. I also have a 24mm tank on there. A shorter 22mm dripper and shorter stem will make it smaller as well.

I used a standard 510 connection and a MOSFET as this is the prototype and I had one lying around but you should be able to fit a DAN30 in there( not sure where the screen would fit though and I didnt have one lying around). Printed with support in PETG with 8 of 3x2mm magnets to hold the lid down.

I just realized I have not added the source file. It has just been uploaded with a change from the original STL. I brought the 510 connection 5 or 6mm closer to the body to make the overall length a bit shorter. I also removed the little shelf inside and square section around the button inside. This was so no support it printed inside to the top. Just in the neck. If you print with PLA you prob wont need any support in the neck either. The PETG doesn't do overhang very well.

Pipe body.stl is the one in the pic
Pipe body Shorter stem.stl is the shorter version. Printing now.
The Fusion file included is the shorter stem version.

The stem is from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:183485/#comments

2/12/16 UPDATE. Been vaping beautifully for a few weeks now. I just cut the model in half so I can print with no external support for a even better finish. Also to help with prebuilding a nice wiring harness then just drop it in and glue it together.

title: Reach 3D Printer - brackets for makerbot limit switches

description.text: Install the open source makerbot v1.2 limit switches on your Reach 3D printer with these limit switch holders and end stops. Note that the x endstop requires a M3 bolt and the y endstop is a simple cap for an M5 bolt. Your kit may have included an M3 bolt for y so some hot glue or tape may be required. The y endstop was designed to accommodate the shifted bed mod for installation of an E3D hot end (shorter hot end requiring table to be moved out slightly). The cap can be rotated or possibly eliminated if you have not shifted your table.

Revised version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1884080
The chassis is now a lot less bulky and consists of multiple parts, the pulleys move more easily now.

Before printing everything it is best to print a couple chain links to see if they work. When using multiple links per step the chain link with the socket on top can be used to connect both the horizontal and vertical parts of one step, the link without the socket can be used in between. The pulley should be big enough that the chain with the mounted steps can bend around it, so it is best to print one of the pulleys next to try that out. The pulleys with the mounted chain are placed on the axes in a way that the hole in the chassis aligns with the square hole of one of the pulleys. Make sure the pulleys rotate easily. You will need 12 pins to assemble the chassis and mount the handle and stands. Inserting the pins can be quite tough, I did it carefully with pliers and a hammer. The crank can be joined with the handle and mounted trough the hole of the chassis with pins. The pictures should give a good overview how the parts connect together.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4Vwmq8cUYPs

This was designed to help accommodate a belt pulley that was slightly wider due to putting a pulley around the normal bearings on the x and y carriage idler. I had trouble with the belt tending to rub against the side so wanted an actually pulley on the bearings but that always interfered with the bracket.

description.text:
a fun game I use to play as a kid.

https://www.tinkercad.com/users/cuuFmHKaorv-fmcquatters

http://www.spanishplayground.net/traditional-game-top-printable/

These are the traditional instructions:
Toma uno. – Take one (token from the pile).
Toma dos. – Take two (tokens from the pile).
Toma todo. – Take it all (the whole pile).
Pon uno – Put one (in the pile).
Pon dos – Put two (in the pile).
Todos ponen. – Everyone puts a token in the pile.

When toma todo comes up, in order to continue, everyone must put one token in the pile. Play continues until one person has all the tokens.

All my models are printed on a Prusa i3 kit. You can find the one I use by clicking the link below. You can get 15% off by using code "GBTE"

12/20/2017 Parts list and some files have been updated. The old files are in a zip file. All hardware kits shipped after 12/18/2017 will have the updated parts.

Complete hardware kits are now available. I partnered with MakerRX. Head over to their page to purchase my kit and get 10% off HatchBox/ColorFabb Filament which is some of the best filament that you can get for the price.
https://www.makerrx.com/products/mrx1
Kits include all non printed parts, 500 rpm dc motor, speed controller, power connectors, and DC power supply.

Email me at [email protected] for international

Working model of a Chevy Camaro LS3 V8 engine.
Over 200 hours of printing!!! Engine block alone was 72 hours.
Modeled from cad files, pictures, specs, and service diagrams of the engine. I did not have the actual engine for this one.
It assembles just like the real thing!!!
https://youtu.be/iAkzb1nXzwU

Also the engine stand will be available for sale soon, if enough people are interested.
It fits my other engines too.

The electric motor that powers it is a 12V 500rpm geared motor.

comments.text: Sorry for posting it here and in the support group, but my camshaft appears to be too short for the engine block yet I printed everything at the normal scale? Do the parts have to be printed at different scales than 100%? Really wish there were more thorough assembly instructions.
comments.author: bmeissen

comments.text: It looks like your Z axis is off. You might need to calibrate your Z axis or it could be a problem with your initial layer. Remember that your printer prints at X layer height so that could mean that your part could be off +/- .1mm or more. If your initial layer height isn't proper then your print could be off another -.1mm or more. So add up all those errors over 28 parts and you can have a cam shaft that's 5mm too short. If you can't get the height of each part right you can try printing the cam parts on a raft. The final height of each part should be higher than the required length and you can just file off the excess. An easy way to check your Z axis is to use your slicer to check the z axis print height and compare that to the final part. See what your slicer says the engine block height should be and measure.
comments.author: bmeissen

comments.text: The support material for the rocker arms needs to be removed with a razor blade to separate the layers. On the underside of the rocker you'll see two narrow slots. Remove the material between. There should be a square hole. The exhuast manifolds print fine in Cura. I'll look at them later and see about modifying them.
comments.author: Deim

comments.text: http://rpmengine.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/20160305_095145-e1457226626296.jpg
comments.author: ericthepoolboy

comments.text: Yes, there should be two gaps on the vertical wall. All material between the gaps should be removed. Look at the rocker arm in the thingiverse viewer. It shows the gap. Some slicers might not recognize it as a gap and just skip over it.
comments.author: Deim

comments.text: Found an easier way to remove the rocker arm "support:"
comments.author: ericthepoolboy

comments.text: Now I do understand what do you mean. I will try it on my rocker arms, but I doubt it will get delaminated without braking, since there is no interface layers like on the real support matterial. I suppose you could increase the distances between the actual part and the support, so razor blade delaminates exactly the layer you want to. Or actualy leave it blank and print with real support and just file the hole square. I don't know, but this way it is "complicated. :)
comments.author: ericthepoolboy

comments.text: I tried to design this part with support and without support. With support designed in to the part, my slicer did not proper print it. Printing the part without built in support and allowing the slicer to add support, caused more problems also. The size of the hole needs to be the same as the mounting surface on the rocker rail, printing with support will cause that distance to be smaller and it also cause the first couple layers of the inner circle to not print properly. I will upload a part file without support later, but printing the current part and using a razor blade to break off the "support" is what i found to work best. It probably wont break off at the exact layer but you would just use the razor blade to cut off the layers.
comments.author: Deim

comments.text: You could possibly cut it in half but the cam is held in place by a "press fit". So if you glue it together then the cam might split it apart if the fit is too tight or it my slide around if its too loose. I'll take a look at the block and see if there anyway I can modify it to cut it in half and have it screw together instead of gluing.

comments.text: Cutting it in half and attaching it with screws doesn't look like it would be practical. The holes and fasteners would end up in weird location. Your best bet it to cut it down the middle, print, then flat sand gluing surface, and use a quality super glue. Should be string enough considering the surface area to be glued.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed these parts at 60mm/s with a flow rate of 120% at 220c hot end and 70c hotbed with white PLA (Real brand). It took around 500g of plastic to complete, minus one or two reprints Some of the parts need supports (everywhere setting, the parts with internal holes). It takes a long time to print all of the parts., Make sure your printer is not under extruding(watch for holes in the infill, turn up flow rate and/or temperature) or screw threads might end up weak. Perhaps turning up shell thickness with even less infill can have good results, but I haven't tried.

description.text:
An enclosure for the power supply that shipped with my g2s. I include an image with the power supply screw hole dimension. If you want to make this case make sure you check these dimensions are correct first. Also, I include an image with the additional parts required for the build and some assembly steps.

Safety note:

If you have nylon m3 x 20, m3 x 10 and m3 nut, they'd make a safer alternative for attaching the fan and power plug. Either that or connecting the metal screws to earth terminal with earthing wire and loop crimps. The other screws pose little risk as they are enclosed in plastic.

In the event of a mains wire getting loose, exposed, unearthed metal screws and nuts are not ideal and really should be earthed(chance they could become conductors for the mains wire if there's physical contact). If you can't be bothered to run earth to these metal parts (like me), it's best not to poke around at the back of the thing when it's plugged into the mains supply.

A super lazy solution could be to put a crap load of hotglue over the exposed metal parts on the inside, maybe some liquid electrical tape(never used this stuff myself). However, if you use PLA things might get melted with hot glue.

When I get time I might make a plastic clip solution for attaching the fan to the case without metal screws, will see how noisy and functional it is. I will post it if it's not horrible.

Included in thing files is the .dwg from Autocad 2012.

This case for iPhone for is designed to be suspended by strings to a set of balloons (not sure how many - yet) so your iPhone can take aerial videos (not sure if there are also apps that can take automatic snapshots without requiring the press of the "shutter button"). It is intended to be tied to another similar case for use as tethered remote control with four strings to adjust the orientation. I NEED TO WIN A MAKERBOT! So I can be inspired to make more "thingis". This thing was derived from Odd Case
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18847 This is an experimental case and have not yet been printed or tested.

WARNING: If you use this, you assume all the risk of potential loss of your phone, damages, injury and death.
This design has not been printed or tested.
  • Print two copies, one for the phone and one for remote control
  • Install the case on your phone.
  • Tie a light string or thread between the two cases, one for each corresponding eyelet. The strings should be the maximum length you need for the height you want to take videos of.
  • Tie enough balloons to lift the phone off the ground (but make sure it is not too much or it might also lift you away!)
  • Put your phone on video recording mode , hold the remote control and launch your phone!
  • Adjust the orientation to the desired angle.
  • Post your videos on YouTube!

Be sure to print two Transitions, Red Buttons and Silver Buttons. All of the STLs are in the orientation I printed them. Personally, I printed the Upper Emitter A with supports generated in Cura.

Unlike Maul's hilt, the two sides are not identical, each side is different to cut down on the support needed. title: Flashforge Dreamer/Creator Pro Glass Bed Bracket - modded for easy removal of glass bed.

description.text:
This is a remix of Makersome's corner bracket for Flashforge Dreamer/Creator Pro glass bed upgrade http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:715545

I have removed the lip that clamps the glass down and instead added a slit and a knobbly bit on each corner to provide pressure on the bed but still making it easily removable without having to undo the wing nuts. Tested and works great.

The print pictured was just a test print at 20% 0.2mm, 3 top layers, 3 bottom layers and 3 outer shells. I have since printed a set of 4 in ProtoPasta HTPLA matte black fiber at 100%, 0.2mm and baked them in the oven at 110 degrees C for 60 mins.

No support required

description.text:
This are printable extruder holders for the MakerBot. They are a replacement for the standard Dinos.
These holders are a little bit lower than the original dinos since I need them that way for a new Printruder design (coming soon). But they should be still usable as drop in replacement with a standard MK3/MK4 extruder.

• Print the four parts
  • Use the standard M5 bolts to bolt each pair of holder parts to the z stage
  • Use M3x35mm bolts (or longer) to attach a Printruder, Extruder or what ever to the stands

description.text: Well i was working on this when the other lure got posted so I wasn't gonna...but then I figured what the 'ell

print. print 2 pins(I strongly suggest you use nails, brads, cotter pins, wire anything else.) Push pins through, pop in iphone add 3 #6 swivels(one in each hole), 2 #8 trebble hooks(to the 2 swivels on fins), tie line to the swivel thats through eye hole. Play "Show me the way to go home", catch a 25 footer. "You know how you know that when you're in the water, Chief? You tell by looking from the dorsal to the tail fin."

This is version 2 of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1846315

I fixed the problem with the joints wearing out quickly. I redesigned the sockets so they are more flexible and should maintain a snug fit. Even if they do become loose over time, you can just put small rubber bands around the base of the sockets to tighten them up again.

If printed in PLA, you don't need rafts.
I included an ABS version with custom rafts (easier to remove) if you have a printer without a heated print plate.
I don't have a heated print plate, so I can't tell you how it would print with one (without rafts).
If you are printing the rafts version of the legs, they are already laid out for you.
If you are printing the non-rafts version, you can print the following:

HeadV3.stl
AbdomenV3.stl
Legs1_V3.stl
Legs2_V3.stl

Or if you want the parts separated, you can print the following:

4 - LegTipLongV2.stl (front and back)
4 - LegTipShortV2.stl (middle 2)
2 - LegMediumV3.stl (back)
6 - LegLongV3.stl (front and middle 2)
8 - LegShortV2.stl (attach to the body)
2 - FangV2.stl
1 - HeadV3.stl
1 - AbdomenV3.stl

Update
Added an alternate head with the eyes as separate shells for 2 color printers.

Update
Per request, I uploaded "HeadV3_Eyes.stl", "HeadV3_No_Eyes.stl", and "Raft_HeadV3_No_Eyes.stl" for slicers that need the files to be separate for 2 color printing. "HeadV3_Eyes.stl" works with the raft version of the head or without.

Also just added "HeadV3_Eyes_Surface_Only.stl". Hard to explain but if you look at it, you will see the difference.

print_settings.Notes:: Support on "FT-5 C-Cooler Layer Fan v60" FROM PLATFORM ONLY!

title: FT-5 Probe Platform PLUS
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
***NOTE: I am using an aluminum plate for my print build surface you may need to use aluminum foil under glass to help out the Inductive Proximity Sensor Switch!!

I was having problems leveling my FT-5 So I took the leap to auto-leveling. Looked around and found a few parts here and there on Thingiverse. Combined them and did some tweaking. Used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1738499 for the Nozzle and Fan, minus the mount. I wanted it a little closer to the bottom of the assembly. Used https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1858771 for a start of a long trip down all the dimensions where a little off road. After days of measuring everything I added the mount for the Inductive Proximity Sensor Switch (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00979RA1M/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). After all that, it was time to thread the wire into the cable chain. What a fun time that was. Wiring it to the "Z" axis end stop location on the control board was easy. Probe Black to Board Green, Probe Brown to Board Red and Probe Blue to Board Black. See picture. Now on to the fun stuff, getting the firmware working. It was about a 3 hour tour. Finally got it! It works like a champ!! I am including it with the files. When you set up the hotend tip and probe, I made the tip about 2.0mm lower than the probe and cooler (see picture). You'll most likely need to do some tweaking to the "Configuration.h" file. It's about half way through the file. I placed a note where to make changes. You'll see it. Anyways, have fun! If you try it out, please post a make and leave your story too!!

Note: Use G29 at the beginning of your print to run auto leveling.

Watch the video! https://youtu.be/FgCBDTnN-CI

UPDATE: 11-26-16 For some reason the note I placed in the firmware configuration.h file for the adjustment wasn't there. I also made a note for adjusting the print size, Mine was a little small. Both notes have big arrows <<<----------------------<<.

UPDATE: 12-26-16 Adjusted the size of the print a bit more.

Update: 3-6-17. Fixed the STL's to fit better and all the holes so no drilling should be needed.

UPDATE 7-17-17 edited the sensor mount by adding a little more adjustment room.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Support on "FT-5 C-Cooler Layer Fan v60" FROM PLATFORM ONLY!

Cleaning up, tapping holes and nuts.

I have a habit of making my models pretty close I'm still learning. Enough said. You'll need to file the top and bottom parts a little to fit.

The two holes in the middle of the top part, two holes in the front for the probe and the two for mounting the cooling head need to be tapped. I use a M3 bolt and one of the through hole parts as a tapping block to keep the threads straight. They are tight but work very well.

The 4 bolt locations in the back part has nut holders. Use a hammer on a flat surface to put the nuts in place. I used M3 nyloc's.

title: Customizable Snowflake Cookie Cutters
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's time to make the holiday cookies! Use this customizer to generate as many unique snowflake cookie cutters as you want, or download the twelve demo models and get baking right away. This Snowflake Cookie Cutter customizer can create over a billion unique designs, so hurry up and get cooking.

Thanks to @matschi for the great idea of turning the Snowflake Machine into a Snowflake Cookie Cutter Machine!

=====

Twitter: twitter.com/mathgrrl
Hacktastic blog: www.mathgrrl.com/hacktastic
Shapeways geekhaus store: www.shapeways.com/shops/mathgrrl

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].

description.header: How to make a Snowflake Cookie Cutter
description.text: Click the "Open in Customizer" button above, then click anywhere in the slider to make a snowflake cookie cutter. If you like it, click the "Create Thing" button, then come back and make some more. If you want a different design, just click somewhere else in the slider. Repeat over one billion times, or until you have enough snowflake cookie cutters for your holiday plans.

Before you do anything, watch the sugar cookie video clip from the Cookie Clause episode of Good Eats, so Alton Brown can show you the basics of making sugar cookies. Trust me, whatever sugar cookie recipe you use, this video will help you do it successfully.

Because your Snowflake Cookie Cutters will be somewhat detailed, it's best to use a very firm sugar cookie dough recipe. I tested my cutters with The Best Cut-Out Sugar Cookies recipe from The Kitchn. Because I am lazy and the cookies were already beautiful and detailed on their own, I didn't bother to decorate them; I just mixed some confectioners sugar and milk to make a glaze and poured it over the cookies. As you can see from the pictures, I might have burned the cookies a little. They were delicious anyway.

Don't have a 3D printer, or want something fancy printed for you? You can get custom snowflake earrings and ornaments made with the Snowflake Machine in our print-to-order shop:

title: Ford Automatic Transmission Tail Housing Plug

description.text: If you've ever removed an automatic transmission, you will usually wind up with a large pool of ATF on the floor of your garage if you don't plug the tail housing where the driveshaft yoke is inserted. I had purchased such a plug at a car swap meet and the seller told me that it should fit a C4 so of course, when I went to use it, it wasn't even close. It was then that I turned to my handy-dandy Geeetech Aluminum Prusa. I mean that's the point of these things right? This plug fits the Ford AOD and C4. The two loops at the closed end are for threading wire through to keep the plug from accidentally being pulled out, which we all know is the kind of thing that happens at the least opportune time; usually when your face is directly beneath the tail housing.

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa Aluminum i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm on a .4 mm nozzle.

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed with 100% infill so that fluid can't seep out between the layers. Used PLA but ABS may be better suited.

I measured a 1968 Mustang driveshaft yoke to get the internal and external dimensions. I then designed a plug in Autodesk Fusion 360 that was long enough to reach into the tail housing but not take too long to print.

title: Mono Price Select Mini Extruder Lever Arm (overbuilt)

description.text:
This is a remix of the other lever arm located at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1743385 but this one has had what I feel are some improvements in function, not necessarily "form".

I overbuilt this version because the replacement at the link above basically replicates the same design (with its inherent flaw)

Changes are:

1 - The spline the bearing sits on is far closer to the factory-designed 3.0mm than the original. I made it 2.89mm to allow for users who may not have their unit dialed in dimension-ally. (If I make a 2.89mm part, it prints out at 2.89mm...that's "dimension-ally")

2 - The bearing area has been raised .35mm to allow the bearing to line up properly

3 - The exterior of the arm itself has been majorly beefed up. By 2 or more mm in most areas, some even more. I don't mind wasting a little plastic here to save a 30hr print down the road.

The included picture is of a prototype I made. The STL file is the beefed up version with a more rounded outer edge (far thicker than stock) behind the bearing and mount and additional braces that are located above and below the filament feed hole.

I have since printed this version but forgot to take a picture of it. It works great and my $200 mono price is back to performing on par with my $2500 makerbot and my FFCP and FFCX. Now if I could just get it to print ABS reliably...lol

Updated to add a pic of thefinal printed part

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro/Creator X/Replicator 2

No

No

.1mm

100%

Notes:

This isn't a part to scrimp on filament considering it can save your butt 18hrs into a 19hr print job. Use 100% infill

author: Jace1969

description.text:
This is my first upload and full disclosure, I haven't printed this yet. I created all three parts in one file and then split the parts so at least in theory, they will slot together cleanly.

I initially made this to hold 3 HDDs but I imagine it's only a matter of time before I get a fourth so I've made a more modular design that will allow for more to be added without printing a whole new dock.

Super simple design should print the right way up but Will probably need at least a small amount of infill. Although I haven't printed this, I've measured and made sure the cables will fit and the drive itself will fit neatly, though I added a slight bit of extra room on the sides in case of any warping while printing (only 1mm on the sides).

Hopefully when I get some filament (only just got my printer) I'll be able to post a photo of the final product.

UPDATE: Inside new models added with a flat base after it was pointed out that the angle may not be good for the spinning drive. I think given that it still spins on the same axis, it should be OK but I'm certainly no expert. New versions added anyway.

description.text:
I'm new on 3D printing, but I want to share my design for the ZX Dandanator Mini! v2 interface, a great interface for the ZX Spectrum computers family.

I've made two different versions of the top: With a hole to allow EEPROM extraction and without it.

11/24/2016 - Added some minor changes
11/27/2016 - Changes in top cover with hole for EEPROM extraction. Internal walls of the hole are now more stronger.
01/03/2017 - Changes in Top & Bottom parts. Now they adjust much better.
02/01/2017 - The housing has been completely redesigned. In the photos you can see the previous design (left) and the new (right). Also, now it's possible to connect another interface on the back expansion bus.
02/04/2017 - Added design for Kempston Joystick mounted in vertical.

Printer:

BQ Hephestos 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Designed in FreeCAD and printed in PLA filament (1.75mm diameter).

Its an adjustable variation of the Heavy Duty printable filament holder.  I was preturbed at close the filament spool had to be to fitting exactly on the hooks, any smaller or larger than the small or large settings made it impossible to put a medium sized spool of PLA (PLA is VERY springy and doesn't like taking on new shapes) on it, I liked the design, but thought it could use a rework.

Print 3 arms, 1 hub, and 3 hooks. The arms may need some "finessing" into their cooresponding dovetails in the hub. I made some design mistakes initially and just recently redesigned them to actually accomodate each other, there is 0.25mm of clearance, am not sure if thats enough because I haven't had a moment to print the new set, also its a rather big part, so you need a mendel sized print bed to make it (200x200, but as small as 150mm in one dimension should be enough). To attach the hooks to the arms, simply get 6 of either 8-32 or M4 screws at least 25mm long and run them through at your desired diameter (the holes may need to be drilled out slightly). Finally get one 608ZZ bearing and mount it on your favorite mounting system, I used the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7001 and the angles from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9559 with 5/16in dowl (lengths are 10.5in(265mm) and 8.5in(215mm) for the struts, width can vary but I used 6in (150mm)) , and it works great!

comments.text: Design is pretty good except for one pretty major flaw: there's nothing keeping the hub from sliding off one side of the bearing. Ideally, the spool should have two bearings, one on each side of the hub, separated by a thin printed wall (that's a part of the hub) between the bearings so the spool can't slide off to one side.

description.text:
I was playing and learning with different software to try better fix these PDO files for printing.

With hours spent and multiple formats split between software I mistakenly messed up retaining the correct size. So be ware some of the files are sized differently so when you choose which file or set of files to print, please be sure you are happy with the size % wise.

I'm told some where round 290mm wide and 315mm deep is an average size to stick with, but hey don't quote me on that. Happy printing Anthony1996 Cheers Chase ; )

comments.text: Hello there. I've printed the file with all split parts but for some reason the two visor parts are not printing good, I've tested something else just incase it was the printer but it wasn't. also I know 3 people including 2 of my friends who have done the same thing such as printing the helmet as they wanted one for themselves and they've got the same problem with the two parts. unfortunately we put the bad parts in the bin other wise we would've shown the problem. Although the same problem happened with the normal phase 2 Arc Trooper version that was uploaded before until the visor section was removed then the parts printed amazingly. is there any chance a modification could be made so the visor section is removed if you have spare time please? so we can finish the helmets and upload photos of the finished masterpieces :) we really appreciate your help.

title: Coin Slot Lid for Canning Jar

description.text: This is a lid with a coin slot to turn any wide or regular mouth canning/mason jar into a bank. The slot is designed for US coins, but you can tweak the slot dimensions in the scad file. This can also be used with a canning jar as a sharps container for razor blades, and other sharps, in the shop or your bathroom. This one was printed with ProtoParadigm's green PLA on a Makergear Mosaic. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19105 for the lid this was based on, and for links to more canning jar accessories. This thing is a part of a collection of things featured in this post: http://www.protoparadigm.com/blog/2012/08/what-to-do-with-a-3d-printer-make-canning-jar-accessories/
Download and print, should work with standard regular or wide mouth canning jars.  Clean up any really loose hairs of plastic on the threads with tweezers and you should be good to go.

description.text:
This quadruped robot is driven by an arduino board and using low price cheap tower pro 9g servo. It has two play modes. One is autonomous which it walks itself randomly in each 5 seconds to different directions. Another is played using an Android app. With ultrasonic distance sensor it will avoid obstacle in front.

Video Demo:
https://youtu.be/QG3WbcEscfI
https://youtu.be/K2RES72E9Pw

Electronics for Demo Built:
1) GSTduino with on-board SPP-C-Bluetooth-UART board.
2) a 3.7V 18650 lithium-ion battery pack (two 18650 batteries in parallel), to charge the battery find our another design.
3) 8 x Tower Pro 9g servo.
4) a HC-SR04 ultrasonic distance sensor. This is optional if you don't want obstacle detection
5) a SPP-C Bluetooth UART or equivalent for Andriod phone control. Baud rate sets to 115200. You don't need to buy separately if you use item 1.

To charge batteries, you can use the charger dock we design.

If you use other Arduino board such as nano, likely you will need a I/O shield for connecting servos. If you are experienced maker, of cause you can use a proto board to customized one. The body of robot is the chamber which can hold two 18650 Lithium-ion batteries. You may have to look after the power regulator too.

Hardware:
1) Dupoint wires
2) Eight M2x4 tapping screws for servo arm clip and M2x6 tapping screws for others

Software:
1) Arduino code on githup
2) Android app on Google Play.

Alternative, you can use the software in our another design thing:2317065, this is the demo https://youtu.be/Htz4qVPmL7Y

Wring:
Connection to digital pins of Arduino are as following -

1) D2 to front right hip servo
2) D3 to front right leg servo
3) D4 to back right hip servo
4) D5 to back right leg servo
5) D6 to back left hip servo
6) D7 to back left leg servo
7) D8 to front left hip servo
8) D9 to front left leg
9) D10 to HC-SR04 trigger pin
10) D11 to HC-SR04 echo pin
11) D12 for play mode selection, to 0V (low state) or 3.3V(high state)
12) Bluetooth UART module to the board's Bluetooth connector

All servos initial angles must set to 90° as the photo showing initial posture. HC-SR04 power input is to 5V pin.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:
  • print two sets of the legs.stl
  • the clips should print in 100% infill

How to play

D12 digital pin is playing mode selection. When D12 is low state the robot is in autonomous walking mode. In this mode, walking direction is randomly changed in every 5 sec. If the ultrasonic distance sensor detects obstacle at the front, it will avoid it.

When D12 is high state, it is controlled by the Android phone, the Bluetooth UART must be installed. To control by the App, firstly pair the Bluetooth UART with your Android phone. Tap setting menu of app to select it. You tap the arrow buttons to control the robot walking.

comments.text:
You can try to use standard Leadscrews but your speed will suffer.
In order to be able to move as fast as a belt driven system you need to have an helix with a high pitch instead of a leadscrew with small pitch.

comments.text: Makes sense, since I'm using NEMA17's with A4982 drivers, I can get them up to a fairly high speed while remaining accurate. I will also be using a 27:1 planetary, so I am considering changing my stepping profiles from 1/16th to 1/8th or numerically higher as well. I will update when I do the conversion, and I will post my parts that I make per usual.

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure to set your slicer to print support everywhere for the bracket.

description.text:
Increased the size of the cone slightly so it'd work better with SeeMeCNC spools, and designed a bracket that mounts tight to a SeeMeCNC Orion's existing side panel.

After a carriage upgrade on my machine, I had some spare 608zz's laying around, so make sure you have those available for the cones.

Metric components being hard to come by in my neck of the woods, and not wanting to order anything online, this is the list of parts I ended up with for the spool holder;
One 5/16 x 6 carriage bolt (I would actually suggest a 6.5 in retrospect.)
Six 5/16 flat washers
Four 5/16-18 hex nuts
One 5/16-18 wing nut

Order of assembly should be bolt / washer / mount / washer / nut / washer / cone / washer / nut / nut / washer / cone / washer / nut / wingnut. The nut/nut combination should be tightened loose to the cone, and tightened hard into eachother to stop the cone from unthreading them as the filament unloads counter-clockwise. Same theory with the nut/wingnut combination. Or you could just find reverse-threaded components...

Update 12/28/16: I was asked the share the source in order to make modifications, so here it is (careful, it's messy :) ).
Checking the SCAD file I also recalled that I used a bevel library as this was my first work (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30336)

This is my first 3d part and I am a beginner at OpenSCAD, so the part is still a bit rough :)

The idea for this part came from seen the "G2S stability improvement" by martinengstrom http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1817718. The lower stabilizer from the kit, really improved the printer shaking, so I decided to make a similar part for the top. I did not want to drill holes (I will make them the first time I need to disassemble the printer), so I made side wings to use Binder clips.

title: Sharp Gantry for Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion

description.text:
This is an adjustment to the awesome Ultimaker 2 Aluminum Extrusion 3D printer by jasonatepaint.

These are the modifications I'm making:

  1. Change all fillet edges to sharp edges, and add bracing to gantry. I'm not a big fan of fillet edge. There are too many round corners in the original built. The relative position of the rods are exactly the same as jasonatepaint's original design.
  2. Change the bolts from M3 to M5, because I will replace some printed connectors for the frame with purchased metal connectors to make it more sturdy. The size of holes on metal parts is often M5/M6. So I changed all the holes of printed gantry to M5 as well.

comments.text: absolutely the perfect remix IMHO, question: So what about the Z axis? Do you use the original M3 version?

comments.text: Unfortunately I discontinued the build because the seperated Z brackets seem to have pretty bad precision. I eventually bought cnc milled aluminum composite frame instead.

description.text: Inspired by a 3x3x3 origami puzzle cube. I wanted to make one with the actual Tetris pieces, which requires at least a 4x4x4 and 16 pieces. The solution I chose uses 4x T, 4x S, 4x L, 2x I, and 2x O pieces. You may find other solutions! My first original 3D design, I'm very proud of how it turned out. Printed in 4 colors of ProtoParadigm PLA in the photo.
